{{also|august}} ==English== {{wikipedia|August (disambiguation)}} ===Etymology 1=== Early {{der|en|enm|August|August(us)}}, re-Latinized from {{der|en|ang|Agustus}}, from {{cog|LL.|Agustus}}, from {{der|en|la|augustus||month of August}}, from the agnomen {{m|la|Augustus||venerable}} of {{w|Augustus|Gaius Julius Caesar Augustus}}, possibly from either Old Latin *''augos'', increase, from {{der|en|ine-pro|-}} base {{m|ine-pro|*aug-||to increase}}; or {{cog|la|avis||bird}}, referring to divination by observing bird flights, singing, feeding or entrails, from Proto-Indo-European *''awi-'', bird; + Latin {{m|la|garrire||to chatter}}, from Proto-Indo-European base *''gar-''/*''ger-'', to cry, of imitative origin ====Alternative forms==== * {{alter|en|Aug|Aug.||abbreviations}} * {{alter|en|Aguste||obsolete}} * {{alter|en|Augost||Jamaica}} ====Pronunciation==== * {{a|RP}} {{enPR|ôʹgəst}}, {{IPA|en|/ˈɔː.ɡəst/}} * {{a|GA}} {{IPA|en|/ˈɔ.ɡəst/}} * {{a|cot-caught}} {{IPA|en|/ˈɑ.ɡəst/}} * {{audio|en|en-us-August.ogg|Audio (GA)}} ====Proper noun==== {{en-proper noun|Augusts}} # {{senseid|en|month}} The [[eighth]] [[month]] of the [[Roman]], [[Julian]], and [[Gregorian calendar]]s, following [[July]] and preceding [[September]]. #* {{quote-book|en|year=1898|author={{w|Winston Churchill (novelist)|Winston Churchill}} |title={{w|The Celebrity}}|chapter=8 |passage=The day was cool and snappy for '''August''', and the Rise all green with a lavish nature. Now we plunged into a deep shade with the boughs lacing each other overhead, and crossed dainty, rustic bridges over the cold trout-streams, the boards giving back the clatter of our horses' feet:{{...}}.}} # {{given name|en|female|from=English}} derived from the month (rare modern usage). #* '''1993''', {{w|Margaret Atwood}}, ''Robber Bride'', Virago Press (2013), {{ISBN|9781853817229}}, page 48: #*: '''''August''''', Charis named her, because that's when she was born. Warm breezes, baby powder, languorous heat, the smell of mown hay. Such a soft name. Too soft for her daughter, who has added an ''a''. Augusta, she is now — a very different resonance. Marble statues, Roman noses, tight-lipped commanding mouths. =====Synonyms===== * {{l|en|Sextilis}} {{qualifier|chiefly early Roman contexts}}, {{l|en|Sextile}} {{qualifier|early Roman contexts, now uncommon}} =====Derived terms===== {{der3|en|[[august]] {{qualifier|verb}} |August Bank Holiday |August plum |August rooster |mid-August}} =====Related terms===== * {{l|en|Augustal}} * {{trans-see|female given name|Augusta}} ====See also==== * {{list:Gregorian calendar months/en}} ===Etymology 2=== In some cases a month name from English. In other cases inspired by the common {{der|en|de|-}} given name {{m|de|August}}, from {{der|en|la|Augustus}}. ====Proper noun==== {{en-proper noun}} # {{given name|en|male|from=Latin}}. #* '''1974''' {{w|Witi Ihimaera}}, ''Whanau'', Heinemann, page 76: #*: Thirteen year old '''August''' is the eldest; he begins to pull the kite downward. Like his sister and brother, June and July, he has been named after the month in which he was born. =====Translations===== {{trans-see|male given name|Augustus}} ===Anagrams=== * {{anagrams|en|a=agstuu|Tausug}} [[Category:English eponyms]] [[Category:English unisex given names]] [[Category:en:Months]] ---- ==Catalan== ===Proper noun=== {{ca-proper noun|m}} # {{l|en|Augustus}} ---- ==Danish== ===Etymology=== Derived from {{der|da|la|Augustus}}. ===Proper noun=== {{da-proper noun}} # {{given name|da|male}}.
